content.description: Easy 5.9/10a corner crack climbing 3/4 of the way up, pull above a small flake to a spicy slab finish. 2 bolts at the top in the slab section. The corner behind a large thick flake, and left of the thin face wall (cursed crack and cursing all the way) Mixed - 2 bolts at the top in the slab section

The extension to Miasmic. Put your granite corner skills to the test. Get on it before - or after - the sun does!

Climb Miasmic to the anchor. Belay here, or even better keep climbing for the full 30m experience. Clip a bolt, then abandon the sweet comfort of the belay ledge entering straight into a puzzling and tenuous corner crux. Don't be lulled by the friendly handcrack above - it's not over. Finish under the roof



Extension to Miasmic.

Miasmic starts with a right-facing handcrack with a chocked flake, into a right-facing corner ramp.

Baby Beluga is a right-facing corner capped with a prominent rectangular roof.

doubles micro to 2"

A short handcrack at the start leads to a mantle and another, steeper handcrack(crux). After this the route continues up a low angle hand and fist crack until it thins down again just before the chains.



1m to the right of David Hasselhoffwidth. Left of Shock Collars for Christmas.

SR with extras in hand - fist sizes. The upper section will eat as many 3s and 4s as you want to bring.

An overlooked but quite obvious natural line, likely remaining unclimbed due to its proximity to the seldom climbed neighboring routes and confusion over where these routes went. It was quite pleasing to nab such an easy FA on this well travelled crag. Face climb past two bolts to the obvious left leaning handcrack which is part of the route Intractable Lassitude. Follow the crack left around the arete where it forms a strenuous hand traverse with bad feet, the crack turns to a vertical hand/fist splitter at the top of this a juggy traverse leads back right to to the anchor of Intractable Lassitude. Another burly Top Shelf 5.11! Located just left of the very popular Eye Catcher. The route starts immediately off of the rope pull that separates to two sectors of Top Shelf. It joins Intractable Lassitude for a tiny bit before breaking left. Two bolts to start and then double set of cams from .4 -3 BD. Bolts and hardware provided by the Sea to Sky bolt fund, please support the bolt fund : https://www.seatoskyclimbing.ca/donate

climbs.name: Crouching Liger
climbs.fa: Drew Marshall, Dee Anna, Nicole Deuchar, Oct 2017

content.description:
This is a wild climb with solid but sometimes tricky gear. It might be worth rappelling in to scope the gear (and maybe some of the moves!) You can access the top anchors by hiking straight down from Kitten Fists. P1Â (11b, 25m) Start as for Maker's Mark, up a fingercrack toward a chimney on the left side of a huge pillar. Use extendable draws generously as you traverse across the front of the pillar, then climb up its right side. Once atop the pillar, clip a bolt and techily traverse a dyke, into a flake system out right. Try not to pump out climbing steep flakes to the big ledge (bolt anchor). Rumour has it that Nicole Deuchar boldly flashed the FA of this pitch before some softy added the bolt P2 (12b, 15m) Climb steep finger cracks to the roof, then pull the roof at a seam with an unlikely sequence. Steep fingers and hands to the top! Descent: 2 raps with a 70 or walk off At the Bottom Shelf wall.
On the way to Top Shelf, just before the trail meets a 30m wall, take the left fork toward Pilot's Lounge instead of going right toward Top Shelf. Walk about 50m until you can see a nice left-facing corner capped with a roof (Maker's Mark)
Alternatively, hike straight down from Kitten Fists to a big mossy ledge to find the top anchors Double camalots 0.2 to 1, Singles 2 to 4, nuts and RPs, 70m rope preferred

Make your way through some awkward moves to gain the thin crack.  Take time to protect the first 15 feet.  Good locks and sporty moves up the steeper-than-it-appears crack get you to a jug and then a bit of a wide section.  Continue up and left in a wide hands, left facing corner.

Immediately left of "Cursing All The Way"
Heavy on fingers and stoppers.  Save a #2 or #3 for the top.  Fixed anchors.

Appropriately named, you won't find many good holds on this climb.  Follow scoops and sloping ledges up the wall, ending at an arete.  Well bolted, but harder, and pumpier than it looks.

100 feet to the right of Eye Catcher.
7 bolts, fixed anchors

Offwidth left of Meltdow



The obvious offwidth/chimney slot

trad

The thin diagonal extension to Baby Beluga. Climb it as a full 40m pitch for best results.

Climb Baby Beluga making generous use of extendable draws. Skip the bolted anchor and instead pull left around the roof and prepare for battle. Here reach deep into your quiver of granite wizardry and sneak past a baffling crux before it notices you. Keep it together for the pumpy finish!

Cool, dry conditions are essential.

Lower with an 80 (mega toprope) or twice with a 60.



extension to Baby Beluga

doubles micro to 1.5", nuts, RPs, many extendable draws

A more direct and striking version of Jason Greens original Demon Sweat. Demon Days starts on Shock Collars For Christmas (all previous known ascents started on Meltdown). Moving past the anchor of SCFC adds an exciting balancing crux (11+) traverse with a precarious high rock over into the start undercling where the original DS comes in from Meltdown. Climb the bulk of the Demon Sweat line, passing the crux (12+/13-) which entails powerful straight on, pressure laybacking off decent inverted incuts. Â Where DS continues following the diagonal left to an anchor DD pulls out into the straight up headwall crack. The straightforward looking fingers to hands size crack throws out a slightly horrendous off fingers crux (12-) right below the top that could tragically thwart the send.Â  Quite an epic pitch! Roughly a double set ranging from tiny cams up to #1BD. Plenty of small to medium nuts, offsets seem to work well. Some triples but which sizes will vary for different people. My specific redpoint rack included 4 .75 size, a 000c3, one #4 camalot. I didn't clip the Shock Collars anchor or the single protection bolt which i believe was designed for protecting the traverse off the SC anchor. Skipping the bolts feels kind of bold and would be spooky on an onsight. If you think you are going up for a working session or to set up a top rope bringing some tiny wires is helpful for aiding through and/or working the crux. 80m rope is perfect for lowering and top roping, otherwise possible to lower twice with a 60m or 70m. You can decrease the physical difficulty of the crux by running it out or decrease the mental difficulty by fiddling in a blind RP. Anchor bolts and hardware provided by the Sea to Sky bolt fund, please support the bolt fund : https://www.seatoskyclimbing.ca/donateÂ

The left-angling crack extension to Meltdown or Shock Collars.
The crux section is either protected blindly or run out, but has a nice clean fall line.
Follow the diagonal crack to the end or fork up at a vertical crack near the top - I'm not sure if the 'direct' finish has been done but it looks nice

2 lower-offs or maybe one with an 80m rope

Camalots - doubles 0.2 to 3, nuts and RPs, optional third set of tips/fingers

Layback flake to a technical bolted arete (crux) and some nice cracks. Very sequency

5 bolts, gear micro to hands. Optional 4 for the bottom

Stem, jam, and layback your way up the beautiful open book with two small roofs.  Starts out thin and gradually widens to thin hands at the top.  Good one for the small handed folks.  Might feel harder if you've got big mitts.

Where the approach trail meets the wall.  It should, dare I say, catch your eye...
Fingers to #1 camalot.  The bottom part takes stoppers very well.  Go heavy on the 0.5, 0.75, and #1 camalots.

Yet another must do pitch at the Shelf.

This route is an extension to Hand Slotter. Although it could be nicely broken into two pitches the best way is to do it is in one 40m pitch, an 80m rope is optimal as it allows you to lower to the ground and set up a sweet mega top rope for all the homies.

Several cruxy sequences lead past the anchor of HS. Charge into the overhanging finger crack, battle crux. Try not to get triggered by the presence of bolts beside the crack, instead focus your attention on whether you can pull off the onsight of this burly beauty.

Double set of cams to #1 BD, 1x  #2, #3 BD, wires. The extension requires a couple of pieces + 4 draws for the bolts.

What a pitch!  Start by climbing a left leaning ramp with 4 bolts.  From the last bolt, head up the finger crack on the face.  A short section of finger locks get you to a powerful move getting in to the pod.  Rest up in the pod and do some thuggy moves to get up and out.  Finish on the easier left facing, low angle corner.  The name made sense to me, hopefully it does for you, too.

About 200 ft. to the right of Eye Catcher
Doubles from fingers - #2 camalot should be fine.  I placed one #3 before the finger crack.  Stoppers.  A 60 m rope JUST gets you down.  Tie knots!!

5.10 climbing out of the alcove leads to steep jams and locks lead to a cruxy face climb section, continue up into the shallow chimney (there is some crumbly rock here, watch where you put your pro) and figure out the final pull to the chains. There are rests, but the wall is steep expect to fight the pump.

On the left side of the cliff, starting out of a small alcove.
Single rack blue alien to #2, doubles from green alien to #0.75. Fixed biners on top.

A corner makes its way to a small roof, and some techy moves up and around it to the top.



Lower Top Shelf - Treasury of Cracks area.

Standard rack.

Short, but quality.  Climb the large flake feature, which starts as fingers and brings you to a no-hands rest.  Rest up and finish with thin hands.  Pumpy!

the furthest left side of the wall
fingers at the bottom and 0.75-1 camalot at the top.  A #2 can be placed halfway, but there are other options.  Most will want at least two each 0.75-1.

Route is split into parts with the first part climbing cracks for 10ft to a mossy ledge. From the ledge climb up and left on laybacks and under clings (protected by two bolts) until able to access the crack above. The crux is busting out left as the crack peters out halfway up the wall.Â 

On the far right side of the crag. Look for a small moss covered ledge with a short crack section below it.Â 
Bolt anchors with chains at the top

This climb is super bad! I mean that in the way that Michael Jackson was Bad. Essentially a harder, and better version of the nearby "Meltdown". The route follows a twin crack system, but the right "crack" is more of just a flare and only usable in a few spots. Make a hard move off the ground and get some good locks and thin, flaring hand jams to a tough move off of a pinch to gain a sloping ledge. Move left on jugs and get a good rest below the thin crack. Place some high pieces and punch it through 20 feet of technical and insecure climbing. Fancy footwork is key to success here as the locks are not that great. Figure out the sequence that works for you and hit the "thank god" hand jam! Some pumpy, 5.9 jamming gets you to the anchors. This felt quite a bit harder to me than Sentry Box, but that's just, like, you know, my opinion. to the left of Eye Catcher, at the top of the fixed line. The gear I used in order was:

gold BD nut
silver BD nut (big one)
0.5 camalot
#1 camalot
#1 camalot
red DMM offset nut
blue DMM offset nut
red BD nut
blue BD nut (big one)
yellow metolius
#2 camalot
0.75 camalot

climbs.name: Maker's Mark
climbs.fa: Jon Rigg, Danny Guestrin, Drew Marshall, June 2017

content.description:
P1 (10a, 20m) Climb a finger crack and/or chimney on the left side of a pillar, to a bolted anchor on a spacious belay ledge P2 (11c, 25m) Climb double cracks up the corner, and an airy layback out the roof. Save a .75 for the lip (chain anchor) Descent: 2 rappels with a 60m, or walk up and off. At the Bottom Shelf wall.
On the way to Top Shelf, just before the trail meets a 30m wall, take the left fork toward Pilot's Lounge instead of going right toward Top Shelf. Walk about 50m until you can see an attractive corner capped with a roof. Doubles fingers to 3

Thin and technical sums it up.  Use twin cracks and the occasional face hold to make your way up.  The cracks have decent locks, but are also a bit flaring.  I was able to get several "finger lock + flared hand jams" and the occasional layback.  Focus on your footwork as you can get good feet in the pods and flares.  The climb broke down to having three hard sections (each harder than the last), separated by good, active rests.  Once you hit the arete, there's still some pumpy finger locks that get you to the chains.

Just left of "Cursed Crack"
Mostly thin up to a 0.5 camalot.  Stoppers.  You can place a #1, but it will get in the way of the only real hand jam!  Fixed anchors.

A left leaning cracked ramp. Lots of hollow sounding rocks so take care placing gear. To the right of the waving looking face that has a bolted route on it and 10ft flake at the bottom of the climb.
Bolted anchor with 2 bail beaners

Follow wide cracks to the roof.  Surmounting the roof is strange, and while I didn't find it to be the crux, I certainly thought it was the "what the hell do I do here?" crux.  I found that chimneying with my left side in was the key to success.  Be smart about your gear at the lip of the roof or the rope will either get stuck on it or suck it deep in to the crack!  Gain the offset, big fingers crack - the feet are thin here, so just keep cranking.  The last few moves pinch down to tight fingers, but there's finally some better feet out left.

75 feet left of "Made From Fire"
Hands to #4 camalot for the bottom and 0.3-0.5 camalots for the upper crack.  Heavy on the 0.5 camalot size.  Stoppers.  2 fixed pieces on the upper crack as of July 2015.

The hands and fingers splitter to the left of Meltdown with lots of interesting and sustained climbing. A testpiece at the grade and one of the best 12a cracks around.  
 Two distinct cruxes and an additional "mounting pump" (ie: clipping the chains) crux as well.

Double rack #0.3-#2.

Start up the corner and make some moves up and right into the double crack system, using either the fingers on the left or hands/fists on the right to the top.



Lower Top Shelf - Treasury of Cracks area. Just left of a big gnarly-blocky roof.

Standard rack to 3 or 3.5

Thin and bouldery crack climbing on the gently overhanging face. Foot features galore. Short and punchy.


cams, nutters

Top Shelf is a relatively new crag in the Squamish area that is stacked with high quality crack lines. The rock is bomber, the routes are clean, and the lines are aesthetic. My hat goes off to the folks who developed this area, as I'm sure it was no easy task to get this wall to the beautiful condition that it's in. The wall faces northwest and gets shade for most of the day. The base of the wall is very well maintained with logs and flat belay areas. Nearly all of the routes can be climbed with a 60 m rope (always tie knots!), most anchors have fixed draws on them for lowering (don't remove them!), and most folks will want a double set of cams from fingers to wide hands and a #4. It would not be out of the question to bring triples up to a #1 camalot, as many of the routes are so splitter! The only thing lacking at this wall are moderates. Most of the climbs are 5.10 and up, and the grades felt a bit harder than similarly graded climbs in the area. The wall is steeper than it appears, so the climbs tend to be pretty pumpy.

There are quite a few projects on the wall. Please respect those as the route developer has put a lot of hard work in to the line.

Additional info can be found at  squamishclimbingsource.wordâ¦
